In 1919 a fishing accident resulted in the deaths of one-third of #Hestur's men. Following that accident and to fight the depopulation of the village a swimming pool was built - it was opened in 1983

The local post office opens just once a week for only 90 minutes

#FaroeIslands

#Hestur (pop. 15) is a #Faroese village on the island of Hestur. Its name refers to the ridge of the #island which resembles the back of a #horse - #hestur in #Faroese.

The 621 metre high #mountain #S√°tan dominates the coastline between #Leynar and #Sk√¶lingur.

#S√°ta is the #Faroese word for a #haystack, and s√°tan is its definite form (but also means #devil / #satan). 

The mountain name refers to its rounded shape.

#Faroese word for #echo literally means "rock wall‚Äôs speech".

#Faroese word for #goose is #g√°s. It comes from From #Proto-Indo-European and is likely of #imitative origin.

The verb at #g√°ka means not only to #quack like a goose, but also to chatter and gossip.

#1N5817 Schottky Barrier Rectifying #Diode is one of many #semiconductors powering modern #technology.

#Faroese word for it is #h√°lvlei√∞ari (#h√°lv -  half-way + #lei√∞ari - conductor), while #electrode is called #kleiv - a word that originally meant a "narrow cleft".

#f√∏royskt

Vita tygum, at ‚Ä¶?  Do you know that white #LED actually emits blue colour? A #chemical compound - called #phosphor - absorbs it and emits a broad spectrum of colours that we perceive as a #white light.

#Faroese word for LED is #lj√≥sdioda (light, lamp, candle + diode)

#f√∏royskt

While most European #languages have quite a similar word for #mathematics, #Faroese just has to be an exception with the word #st√∏ddfr√∏√∞i üôÇ

It comes from the words #st√∏dd (quantity, dimensions) and #fr√∏√∞i (science, -ology).

#f√∏royskt #WordOfTheDay

The #Faroese word for #ivy is #vi√∞bendil. It literally means something that bends and twists (#benda) towards (#vi√∞) / in a certain direction

While #Hedera helix is not found naturally on the #FaroeIslands, it can be bought at local garden centres

#f√∏royskt #flora #WordOfTheDay

#Faroese word for #sticker is #klistrimerki. It literally means "sticky sign" (at #klistra - to stick + #merki = sign).

#f√∏royskt #WordOfTheDay

There are fifteen kinds of #fern in the #FaroeIslands. Most of them grow in clefts in rocks where there is moisture and shade.

The #Faroese word for fern is '#tr√∏llakampar', which means '#troll's beard'.

#f√∏royskt #WordOfTheDay #flora

English #Wikipedia's "{{Citation needed}}" has its #Faroese counterpart - "{{#Kelda vantar}}" (literally "lack of sources").

Always check your #sources.

#f√∏royskt #Faroese @Wikipedia

The #Faroese word for #leaf is #leyv. 

#Deciduous #trees are quite numerous on the islands. In 1979, 6000 small¬†#Nothofagus¬†plants¬†were transferred from¬†Tierra del Fuego to #FaroeIslands, making it the biggest population in¬†Europe.

#f√∏royskt #wordoftheday #Spathiphyllum

Steep mountains - that dominate #FaroeIslands landscape - are of #volcanic origin. Dark layers of #basalt alternate with the softer layers of reddish #tuff - stone made up of volcanic ashes.

These steep mountainsides are called #hamar (rocky wall).

#f√∏royskt #Faroese

There are numerous neologism that brought new meaning to existing words, e.g. r√°s which originally means "sheep track", but is now also means "radio station".

Other words were replaced over time. In the past the Faroese word for woman was kona. Now, kvinna is used.

The #Faroese word #epli originally meant #apple (and still does in biblical and poetical context). However, over time it became the term for #potato (otherwise termed #j√∏r√∞epli = ground apple).

The ‚Äús√∫r-‚Äú prefix comes from the adjective #s√∫rur (sour).

#f√∏royskt

The #Faroese word for #encyclopedia is #alfr√∏√∞i. It translates into "science (fr√∏√∞i) of everything (al)‚Äù

Or√∞i√∞ alfr√∏√∞i merkir "fr√∏√∞i um alt‚Äù - as the Faroese @Wikipedia article defines the noun

Today's #WordOfTheDay is illustrated by the page taken from ‚ÄúHeimur okkara alfr√∏√∞‚Äù.
Pictured is the debut album of the folk-metal band #Hamradun released in 2015. #Music CD would be called #lj√≥mfl√∏ga in Faroese.

Many #Faroese #neologisms reuse existing words. The word ‚Äú#fl√∏ga‚Äù is not an exception. With its original meaning being the layer on a stack (of hay) and thick slice (of bread) it now also means the compact disc (#CD). The thick layer of data, perhaps?

#f√∏royskt #Hamradun

The #Faroese word for #cloud is #sk√Ωggj. But there are a few dozen more specific ones.

Like #ny√∞ra - fleecy cloud, which also means ‚Äútuft of #wool‚Äù. Or #r√≥√∞rarsk√Ωggj - cloud which drifts slowly, not faster than the speed of a rowboat (#r√≥√∞rarb√°tur)

#f√∏royskt #WordOfTheDay

#Faroese word for #museum is #savn. It comes from the verb ‚Äúat savna‚Äù - to gather, to round up (sheep).

The skeleton of the Pilot Whale at the exposition of the #Tj√≥√∞savni√∞ (#FaroeIslands National Museum).

The #Gj√≥gv incline railway is the only operating #Faroese #railway, transporting goods and small boats. The #narrow-gauge line follows a steep incline in the local #harbour.

#sporsmalur = spor - rail, #track + smalur - narrow, small

Between #Ei√∞i and #Funningur lies the highest #Faroese mountain - #Sl√¶ttaratindur (#sl√¶ttur refers to the summit‚Äôs flat surface)

Since 2012 its elevation is no longer 882 meters, but "only" 880 m. But it's still one of ten mountains which rise to over 800 m ASL

The #Faroese native #Angelica archangelica (#hvonn) was gathered in the wild and cultivated in gardens. It was served as a dessert, with cream or thick sour milk.

The village of #Hvannasund took its name from the plant - it's "the sound of angelicas".

#Haraldssund (pop. 67) is located on the east coast of #Kunoy and was probably founded before 1200.

#H√∫sar (pop. 35) is the most populated and the oldest village on #Kalsoy. Its name is a plural form of the #Faroese word ‚Äúh√∫si‚Äù - a house. The village stone church was built in 1920.

#S√∏rv√°gur (pop. 1152) lies on the island of #V√°gar. Its name can be of  #OldNorse origin - coming either from words #seyr (sand) or #saurr (mud, dirt).

The place can also be named after #S√∏rli - the first man who is believed to settle here.

#FaroeseCities #FaroeIslands

#G√°sadalur (pop. 13) is situated in a deep valley (#dalur)

It‚Äôs said its name comes from a woman named #G√¶sa - the wife of a 12th century bishop - who according to legend was the one who founded the village

#g√°sa is also a #Faroese word for a goose

#FaroeseCities #FaroeIslands

#Faroese #linguist and scholar Jakob Jakobsen proposed that the island name #Mykines derived from¬†mykr/mykja¬†‚Äòmuck‚Äô +¬†nes¬†‚Äòheadland, cape‚Äô (relating to the huge amount of bird droppings to be found there).

#f√∏royskt #FaroeIslands

#Mykines (pop. 15) is the only settlement on the westernmost #Faroese island. It‚Äôs the only place where the¬†#gannet nests.

The peculiar name of the island likely has #Gaelic roots. It originates from the #Celtic words *Muc-innis meaning pig-island.

#V√≠karbyrgi was heavily hit by the #BlackDeath in 1349 - only one woman, called #Sneppan survived the plague. The long isolation meant that she did not want to have contact with others. She did not die of hunger, thanks to men from #Sumba who hoisted dried meat down to her.

#V√≠karbyrgi (now #abandoned) was in the #MiddleAges one of the largest settlements on #Su√∞uroy. It is considered one of the oldest settlements in the #FaroeIslands.

Its name comes from the #Faroese words #v√≠k - bay and #byrgi - enclosed place / animal shelter.

#FaroeseCities

#Morskranes (pop. 15) lies on the west coast of #Eysturoy.

Its name - according to Eivind #Weyhe - may come from strongly inflected form of the #Faroese noun¬†#skurur - young bird of lesser black-backed #gull (#LarusFuscus).

#FaroeseCities #FaroeIslands #f√∏royskt #fauna

The #Sk√¶lingsfjall mountain was long thought to be the #FaroeIslands highest.

The original name  of the mountain used to be #Sk√¶lingur. Later on it got the #fjall suffix (mountain) to tell it apart from the village.

The small settlements of #Sk√¶lingur (pop. 13) lies on #Streymoy at the foot of the #Sk√¶lingsfjall mountain (767 m).

The ‚Äúsk√¶li‚Äù prefix comes from the #Faroese noun #sk√°li (house). The mountain is said to resemble the shape of a #house.

#FaroeseCities #FaroeIslands #f√∏royskt

The small #watermill in #Skarvanes is powered by the #Matar√°in stream. That name is quite frequent on #FaroeIslands and means "brook from which water was taken for cooking".

They say that during the waves of #smallpox the people of #Skarvanes forbade anyone to cross the stream.

#Skarvanes (pop. 9) is perched on low cliffs with no safe landing-place. A small #watermill can be found when entering the settlement

The place name may refer to #skarvur - #cormorants which likely frequented the coast here in the past.

#FaroeseCities #FaroeIslands #f√∏royskt

From all the other places on #Sandoy one goes ‚Äúheim til Sands‚Äù when travelling to #Sandur, which is hence considered the home (heim) or mother settlement from which the others developed.

#FaroeseCities #FaroeIslands #f√∏royskt

#Sandur (pop. 527) is the largest and oldest settlement on #Sandoy. It's the site of the church, below which are five earlier ones (a wooden stave church being the oldest one, from c 1100)

The town‚Äôs name in #Faroese means sandy beach, stretch of sand

#Sk√°lav√≠k (pop. 138)¬†is the northernmost and the oldest village on the east coast of #Sandoy.

Its name may refer to #sk√°li - an assembly hall from the village early days - or to #sk√°l - bowl-like shape created by the surrounding hills.

Villages named #Sy√∞radalur lies on #Streymoy and #Kalsoy. Their name is formed by #Faroese words #sy√∞ri (southerly) and #dalur (valley)

#Sy√∞radalur on Streymoy (pop. 9) was first mentioned in 1590. Today it consists of just one farm

Surrounded by high mountains #Nor√∞radalur (pop. 10) enjoys a great view of the island of #Koltur.

#Kaldbak name comes from words #kaldur (cold) and #bakki (steep slope, hill)

Nearby summit  #Kaldbakskambur may have been named  from the north facing (hence cold and dark) side. When #Kaldbak was founded by the southern slope it got its name from the nearby hill

#Stykki√∞ (pop. 37) lies on the west coast of #Streymoy and was founded in 1845. It‚Äôs hence one of so called ‚Äúsettlement villages‚Äù (#ni√∞ursetubygdir)

Over 470 #lichen species are found on #FaroeIslands. Birch bark from abroad may have contributed much to the introduction of new ones.

#Nor√∞toftir (pop. 3) is a tiny settlement on #Bor√∞oy.

The #Faroese word #toftir means ‚Äúthe remains of the houses‚Äù and may indicate that this place was once depopulated. The "nor√∞" prefix (northern) was added when the local postal service was established.
